subdebateinfo.title: Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement: Old-growth Eucalyptus
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 513)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 9 March 1999:

question.para: Following the Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement, how much:
(a) old-growth Eucalyptus regnans is protected in dedicated reserves in Tasmania;
(b) old-growth Eucalyptus obliqua (wet) is protected in dedicated reserves in Tasmania;
(c) old-growth Eucalyptus delegatensis (wet) is protected in dedicated reserves in Tasmania;
(d) old-growth Eucalyptus viminalis (wet) is protected in dedicated reserves in Tasmania;
(e) old-growth Eucalyptus regnans is protected in proposed and existing informal reserves in Tasmania;
(f) old-growth Eucalyptus obliqua (wet) is protected in proposed and existing informal reserves in Tasmania;
(g) old-growth Eucalyptus delegatensis (wet) is protected in proposed and existing informal reserves in Tasmania; and
(h) old-growth Eucalyptus viminalis (wet) is protected in proposed and existing informal reserves in Tasmania;

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement (RFA) includes a comprehensive, adequate and representative (CAR) Forest Reserve System of Formal Reserves, Informal Reserves and values managed by prescription. Boundaries of some new reserves are still being finalised by the Tasmanian Government in accordance with the RFA. I assume that by dedicated reserves Senator Brown means formal reserves. Noting that the boundaries of reserves are still being finalised the following approximate areas are provided. The provisional boundaries of the CAR reserve system provide for the protection of the following area of old growth forest communities in existing and proposed Formal Reserves:
(a) old-growth Eucalyptus regnans forestâ4 600ha (35%)
(b) old-growth wet Eucalyptus obliqua forestâ35,900 ha (43%)
(c) old-growth wet Eucalyptus delegatensis forestâ50,100 ha (48%)
(d) old-growth wet Eucalyptus viminalis forestâ100 ha (71%)
and in existing and proposed Informal Reserves:
(e) old-growth Eucalyptus regnans forestâ1,700 ha (13%)
(f) old-growth wet Eucalyptus obliqua forestâ9,000 ha (11%)
(g) old-growth wet Eucalyptus delegatensis forestâ7,900 ha (8%)
(h) old-growth wet Eucalyptus viminalis forestâ0 ha (0%)
Percentages are based on the total area of forest reserved for each forest type.

subdebateinfo.title: Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement: Astacopsis gouldi
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 514)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 9 March 1999:

question.para: (1) With reference to Attachment 2 of the Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement, which implies that a recovery plan has been completed and is being implemented for Astacopsis gouldi: is this the case.
(2) Has Environment Australia adopted the recovery plan for Astacopsis gouldi completed in August 1997; if not, why not.
(3) Has the Tasmanian Government adopted the recovery plan for Astacopsis gouldi completed in August 1997; if not, why not.
(4) (a) What implementation actions for recovery of the species are committed and/or under way; (b) how much money has been allocated; and (c) what are the completion dates for the actions.
(5) If no recovery plan has been adopted what steps have been implemented to prevent pre-emptive logging or road construction in areas which might impact on the species.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) A recovery plan was finalised in 1997. Natural Heritage Trust funds have been allocated for two sub-actions.

(2) The Tasmanian Parks and Wildlife Service have not yet submitted this recovery plan to Environment Australia for adoption, as events in the two years since it was prepared have necessitated some revision of the plan. The Tasmanian Parks and Wildlife Service will be proposing some changes to the plan at a Recovery Team meeting to be held in April.
(3) The Tasmanian Government has not adopted the recovery plan. The Tasmanian Government has reconvened the recovery team to review the plan in the light of current knowledge.
(4) (a) The recently signed contract for 1998/99 provides Endangered Species Program funds for two sub-actions of the recovery plan: community involvement and localised population monitoring.
(b) Natural Heritage Trust funds approved for 1998/99 amount to $48,200.
(c) The completion date for the project is 31 January 2000.

(5) The Forest Practices Code for Tasmania details prescriptions to manage rivers and streams to negate any detrimental impacts of forestry activities. Under the threatened species notification system, a notification form must be completed for any forestry activity that is planned within the known range of a threatened species. Conservation measures include establishment of streamside buffers, retention of nature conservation strips and habitat clumps.
